policyFindings: In-cabin: Only cats and dogs are accepted and only on specific Air Tahiti Nui–operated routes. As of the GSC effective 26 Mar 2025, eligible routes are Papeete–Paris CDG, Papeete–Los Angeles, Papeete–Seattle, Paris–Los Angeles, and Los Angeles–Paris CDG; inbound to Papeete (e.g., Los Angeles–Papeete) is not listed. Website shows a shorter list; defer to the dated GSC.
In-cabin: Must be on flights operated by Air Tahiti Nui; service subject to availability (quota).
In-cabin size/weight: Maximum combined pet + carrier weight is 8 kg (17.6 lb). One carrier per passenger; up to two small pets allowed in one carrier if total ≤ 8 kg and they have room to move.
In-cabin carrier: Must fit under the seat; maximum exterior dimensions 40 x 35 x 20 cm (15.7 x 13.7 x 7.9 in); soft or rigid carrier permitted.

In-cabin age/health/ID: GSC requires animals be at least 3 months old and vaccinated. For travel to or via the United States, cats must be ≥4 months and dogs ≥6 months per CDC rules; microchip required for U.S. travel. For France, microchip or pre-3 July 2011 tattoo; other destinations: microchip.
In-cabin documents: Veterinary health certificate/passport required; send the requested health certificate to ATN reservations on or after 48 hours before departure.
In-cabin sedation: Sedation is not allowed; waiver requires attestation that the animal is not under tranquilizers.

In-cabin fees: Fees vary by route/currency. Listed examples: Los Angeles–Paris USD 150; Paris–Los Angeles EUR 150; Papeete–Los Angeles XPF 14,000; Papeete–Paris XPF 24,000. Seattle is listed as eligible in the GSC but no fee shown on the website; confirm with ATN.
In-cabin booking and changes: Book via ATN agencies, phone, travel agencies, and at the airport in Papeete and Paris (only). Refund/change rules are specified in the GSC.

Breed/type restrictions: Dogs categorized as dangerous under French regulations (e.g., Pit Bull, American Staffordshire Terrier, Rottweiler, Dogo Argentino, Fila Brasileiro, Broholmer, Mastiffs incl. German, Bordeaux, Bullmastiff, Neapolitan; Bulldog; Cane Corso; Tosa; and crosses) are prohibited.

Brachycephalic restriction: Brachycephalic (snub-nosed) dogs and cats are not accepted in the hold; the in-cabin waiver requires attesting the animal is not brachycephalic, effectively excluding brachycephalic pets from cabin as well.
Emotional Support Animals: ESAs are not considered service animals and must travel under the pet policy if accepted.

Service animals: Defined as individually trained to assist a person with a disability; pets and ESAs excluded. Up to two service dogs or one service cat per passenger permitted. Must stay at handler’s feet or on lap without encroaching on others; cannot block aisles or exits. Leash/harness and muzzle are mandatory; ATN may require their use and may deny boarding for aggressive behavior.

Service animal documents: Veterinary health certificate/passport required. For U.S. travel, U.S. DOT Service Animal Air Transportation Form and Service Animal Relief Attestation are required at check-in; U.S. CDC dog-entry rules also apply.

Pets in the hold (cargo): If not accepted in cabin or on non-eligible routes, cats and dogs may be shipped via Air Tahiti Nui Cargo on main stations including Paris CDG, Papeete, Auckland, Los Angeles, Tokyo Narita. Rates are weight/destination-based; ATN provides a price estimator (from Papeete). For other departures, contact a specialized forwarder.

Cargo crate: IATA-compliant crate with two interlocking plastic shells secured by metal threaded rods; metal door with four locking rods extending at least 1.6 cm beyond top and bottom; ventilation on front/sides/back; sized so the animal can stand, turn, and sit; muzzle must not pass through the grid.

Cargo restrictions: Specific breeds (e.g., Pitbull, American Staffordshire, etc.) and brachycephalic dogs/cats are not accepted; females in estrus or advanced pregnancy are not accepted. Rottweiler-type guard/defense dogs have a special procedure; contact ATN Cargo.

Cargo acceptance (non-U.S. destinations): Pets must be ≥2 months old with up-to-date health record, microchip, rabies vaccination, and a veterinary health certificate. Additional certificate from the Rural Development Office of French Polynesia required for Paris and Auckland.

Cargo to the U.S. (Los Angeles): Dogs must have only resided in rabies-free/low-risk countries in the previous 6 months, be ≥6 months old, microchipped (15-digit ISO), rabies-vaccinated, possess a valid veterinary health certificate, and have a CDC dog import form receipt. Cats must be ≥2 months, microchipped, vaccinated for rabies, and have a valid veterinary health certificate.
notes: Route eligibility discrepancy: The GSC effective 26 Mar 2025 adds Papeete–Seattle and confirms eligible cabin routes, while the website omits Seattle. Use the GSC list; confirm Seattle fees with ATN at booking.

U.S.-bound travel: Current U.S. CDC dog-entry rules require dogs to be ≥6 months, microchipped, and with CDC paperwork; ATN reflects these requirements for both cabin and cargo when the U.S. is involved. Always check current CDC requirements.
No seasonal temperature embargo information is published on the cited ATN pages; confirm any heat/cold restrictions with ATN Cargo at booking.
Prohibited breeds: ATN references French “dangerous dog” categories and provides examples; rely on ATN’s on-site prohibition statements for eligibility.

finalDoc.PetPolicySummary: Traveling with Pets and Service Animals: Air Tahiti Nui allows cats and dogs in the cabin on specific ATN-operated routes only: Papeete–Paris (CDG), Papeete–Los Angeles, Papeete–Seattle, Paris–Los Angeles, and Los Angeles–Paris (CDG). Pets must remain in a suitable carrier that fits under the seat and the combined pet+carrier weight must be ≤ 8 kg (17.6 lb). Maximum carrier size is 40 x 35 x 20 cm (15.7 x 13.7 x 7.9 in). One carrier per passenger; up to two small pets may share one carrier if within the weight/space limits. Availability is quota-limited per flight. Age and identification: Minimum age is generally 3 months with vaccinations current; for travel to or via the United States, cats must be at least 4 months and dogs at least 6 months, and a microchip is required. For France, microchip or a clearly legible tattoo applied before July 3, 2011 is accepted; for other destinations a microchip is required. Required documents include up-to-date vaccination records and a valid veterinary health certificate (including weight, size, breed) to be sent to ATN reservations on or after 48 hours before departure, plus a printed, completed waiver for pets in cabin. Ensure compliance with all entry/transit requirements. Fees for pets in cabin: Los Angeles–Paris USD 150; Paris–Los Angeles EUR 150; Papeete–Los Angeles XPF 14,000; Papeete–Paris XPF 24,000. Contact ATN to confirm fees on other eligible routes (e.g., Seattle). Prohibited animals: Dogs classified as dangerous under French regulations (e.g., Pit Bull, American Staffordshire Terrier, Rottweiler, Dogo Argentino, Fila Brasileiro, Mastiffs including German, Bordeaux, Bullmastiff, Neapolitan; Bulldog; Cane Corso; Tosa; and similar/crosses) are not accepted. Brachycephalic (snub-nosed) dogs and cats are not accepted in the cabin or in the hold. Service animals: Defined as individually trained to assist a person with a disability; ESAs are not service animals. Up to two service dogs or one service cat per passenger are permitted, minimum age 4 months. The animal must stay at the handler’s feet or on their lap without encroaching on other passengers or blocking aisles/exits. Leash/harness and muzzle are mandatory; ATN may require their use and may deny boarding for unsafe behavior. Documents: veterinary health certificate/passport; for U.S. travel, the U.S. DOT Service Animal Air Transportation Form and Service Animal Relief Attestation are required at check-in and U.S. CDC dog-entry rules apply. Pets not accepted in cabin or on non-eligible routes may be shipped via ATN Cargo in an IATA-compliant crate; additional age, health, identification, and destination-specific rules apply, including CDC requirements for dogs entering the U.S.
finalDoc.ImprovedPetPolicySummary:
Air Tahiti Nui — Pets and Service Animals

Pets in the Cabin (PETC)

  • Eligible routes on ATN-operated flights only: Papeete–Paris (CDG), Papeete–Los Angeles, Papeete–Seattle, Paris–Los Angeles, Los Angeles–Paris (CDG). Inbound to Papeete is not eligible.
  • Accepted species: cats and dogs.
  • Minimum age: generally 3 months with vaccinations current. U.S. travel: cats ≥ 4 months; dogs ≥ 6 months (per CDC).
  • Identification: microchip required for U.S. and most destinations; France accepts microchip or a clearly legible tattoo applied before 3 Jul 2011.
  • Carrier and weight: pet must remain in a soft or rigid carrier that fits under the seat; max external size 40 x 35 x 20 cm (15.7 x 13.7 x 7.9 in). Combined pet + carrier weight ≤ 8 kg (17.6 lb).
  • One carrier per passenger; up to two small pets may share one carrier if within limits and with sufficient space.
  • Subject to quota/availability per flight. Sedation/tranquilization is not permitted.

Documents & Process

  • Up-to-date vaccination records and a valid veterinary health certificate (including weight, size, breed).
  • Email/send the requested health certificate to ATN reservations on or after 48 hours before departure.
  • Printed, completed waiver for pets in cabin must be presented at check-in.
  • Comply with all entry/transit/import rules for departure, transit, and destination countries. For U.S. travel, CDC dog-entry rules apply.

Fees (examples)

  • Los Angeles–Paris: USD 150
  • Paris–Los Angeles: EUR 150
  • Papeete–Los Angeles: XPF 14,000
  • Papeete–Paris: XPF 24,000
  • Contact ATN to confirm fees on other eligible routes (e.g., Seattle).

Restrictions

  • Prohibited: dogs categorized as dangerous under French regulations (e.g., Pit Bull, American Staffordshire Terrier, Rottweiler, Dogo Argentino, Fila Brasileiro, Mastiffs incl. German/Bordeaux/Bullmastiff/Neapolitan, Bulldog, Cane Corso, Tosa, and similar/crosses).
  • Brachycephalic (snub-nosed) dogs and cats are not accepted in cabin or hold.

Service Animals

  • Definition: individually trained to assist a person with a disability (ESAs are not service animals).
  • Allowance: up to two service dogs or one service cat per passenger; minimum age 4 months; animal must be identified (microchip per destination rules).
  • On board: must remain at handler’s feet or on lap without encroaching on others or blocking aisles/exits. Leash/harness and muzzle are mandatory; ATN may require their use and may deny boarding for unsafe behavior.
  • Documents: veterinary health certificate/passport. For U.S. travel, U.S. DOT Service Animal Air Transportation Form and Service Animal Relief Attestation are required at check-in; CDC dog-entry rules apply.

Pets in the Hold (Cargo)

  • If not eligible for cabin or route, cats and dogs may travel via ATN Cargo in an IATA-compliant crate.
  • General (non-U.S.): pets ≥ 2 months, microchipped, rabies-vaccinated, with a valid veterinary health certificate; destination-specific permits may apply.
  • To the U.S. (dogs): must have only been in rabies-free/low-risk countries in the past 6 months, be ≥ 6 months, microchipped (15-digit ISO), rabies-vaccinated, with a valid veterinary health certificate and CDC Dog Import Form receipt. Cats: generally ≥ 2 months, microchipped, and with a valid veterinary health certificate.
finalDoc.inCompartmentDetails: Cats and dogs allowed on select ATN-operated routes only (PPT–CDG, PPT–LAX, PPT–SEA, CDG–LAX, LAX–CDG). One under-seat carrier (max 40 x 35 x 20 cm) per passenger; up to two small pets in one carrier; total pet+carrier weight ≤ 8 kg. Minimum age generally 3 months (U.S.: cats ≥ 4 months; dogs ≥ 6 months). Microchip/ID per destination. Health certificate and waiver required; send requested health certificate to ATN reservations on or after 48 hours before departure. Subject to flight quota. Brachycephalic pets and dangerous dog categories are not accepted.
finalDoc.inCargoDetails: If not eligible for cabin or on non-eligible routes, cats and dogs may be shipped via Air Tahiti Nui Cargo in an IATA-compliant crate. Age, health, microchip, rabies vaccination, and destination-specific entry rules apply. For U.S.-bound dogs: only from rabies-free/low-risk countries in last 6 months, ≥ 6 months old, microchipped, rabies-vaccinated, valid health certificate, and CDC Dog Import Form receipt required. Brachycephalic breeds and dangerous dog categories are not accepted.
finalDoc.carrierCompartmentDetails:
In-Cabin Carrier Details

Conditions for accepting and transporting pets in the cabin with Air Tahiti Nui:

  • Only vaccinated cats and dogs are accepted.
  • Pets must be identified as follows:
    • To the United States: microchip required.
    • To France: microchip or tattoo applied before July 3, 2011, and clearly legible.
    • To other destinations: microchip required.
  • Age requirements:
    • Transit through or travel to the United States: cats must be at least 4 months old; dogs at least 6 months old if they have only been in rabies-free or low-risk countries in the past 6 months.
    • Other destinations: cats and dogs must be at least 3 months old.
  • The combined weight of the animal and its carrier must be ≤ 8 kg (17.6 lbs).
  • The pet must remain in an appropriate carrier (soft or rigid) that fits under the seat in front:
    • Maximum dimensions: 40 cm (L) x 35 cm (W) x 20 cm (H) / 15.7 in x 13.7 in x 7.9 in.
    • One carrier per passenger allowed, accommodating up to two small pets if weight and space requirements are met.
  • Availability of in-cabin pet transport is subject to quota per flight.
  • Brachycephalic (snub-nosed) breeds are not accepted in the cabin.
  • Sedation/tranquilization is not permitted.

Mandatory documents:

  • Up-to-date vaccination records.
  • Valid health certificate issued by a veterinarian including weight, size, and breed of the animal. Submit to the reservation service on or after 48 hours before departure.
  • Printed and completed waiver of responsibility and conditions for bringing a dog or cat into the cabin, to be presented at check-in.
  • Import permit issued by the destination country if required. Compliance with all import regulations is the traveler’s responsibility.
Failure to meet import or documentation requirements may result in denied entry, repatriation at passenger's expense, or denied boarding.
For transit through or travel to the United States: CDC regulations for pet and service dogs may change without notice. Regularly check for updates to ensure compliance.

Please verify health and entry requirements specific to your destination with relevant authorities before travel.
finalDoc.carrierCargoDetails:
In Cargo Carrier Details

To ensure the safe transport of your pets in the hold, a certified cage according to IATA standards, approved for long-haul air transport, is mandatory.

  • The crate consists of two plastic half-shells secured with metal threaded rods and nuts/wing nuts.
  • The metal door must have four locking rods extending at least 1.6 cm beyond the top and bottom of the crate frame.
  • Ventilation openings are required on the front, sides, and back.
  • The crate must allow the animal to stand, turn around, and lie down naturally without putting its muzzle through the grid.

Acceptance Conditions for Animals in the Hold

  • Animals must generally be at least 2 months old.
  • Health records must be up to date and a veterinary health certificate is required.
  • Animals must be identified by microchip; rabies vaccination must be current.
  • Brachycephalic (snub-nosed) dogs and cats are not accepted in the hold.
  • Dogs categorized as dangerous under French regulations are not accepted. Contact ATN Cargo for any specific queries.

Additional Requirements for Transport to the United States

  • Dogs must have only resided in rabies-free or low-risk countries during the 6 months before the trip, be over 6 months old, microchipped (15-digit ISO-compatible), rabies-vaccinated, and have a valid veterinary health certificate.
  • A CDC Dog Import Form receipt is required for entry into the U.S.
  • Cats must generally be at least 2 months old, microchipped, and have a valid veterinary health certificate (and any destination-required vaccinations/permits).
finalDoc.serviceAnimalDetails:
Service Animals (In-Cabin)

A service animal is an animal individually trained to assist a person with a disability. Emotional support animals are not considered service animals.

  • Allowance: up to two service dogs or one service cat per passenger.
  • Minimum age: 4 months.
  • Identification: microchip or tattoo per destination rules (U.S.: microchip required; France: microchip or a legible tattoo applied before July 3, 2011).
  • On board: the animal must remain at the handler’s feet or on their lap without encroaching on another passenger or blocking aisles/exits.
  • Leash/harness and muzzle are mandatory; ATN may require their use at any time and may deny boarding for unsafe or aggressive behavior.
  • Documents: veterinary health certificate/passport. For U.S. travel, the U.S. DOT Service Animal Air Transportation Form and the Service Animal Relief Attestation (in English) are required at check-in; U.S. CDC dog-entry rules apply.
